repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: Why? To my knowledge the push and pull_request events are completely separate/unrelated.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,11 @@
 name: "CodeQL"
 
 on:
+  push:
+    branches: [ "master" ]
+  pull_request:
+    # The branches below must be a subset of the branches above

comment_data.body: Schedule shouldn't be needed anymore if we're testing this for every PR anyway.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,11 @@
 name: "CodeQL"
 
 on:
+  push:
+    branches: [ "master" ]
+  pull_request:
+    # The branches below must be a subset of the branches above
+    branches: [ "master" ]
   schedule:

comment_data.body: idk, that's what the codeql default config had. should i remove it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,11 @@
 name: "CodeQL"
 
 on:
+  push:
+    branches: [ "master" ]
+  pull_request:
+    # The branches below must be a subset of the branches above

comment_data.body: Up to you, I just find the comment confusing and misleading. The pull_request event will run on PR openings/updates and the push event will run when the PR is merged, and these are unrelated events. It should be possible to use only the push event or the pull_request event without the other.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,11 @@
 name: "CodeQL"
 
 on:
+  push:
+    branches: [ "master" ]
+  pull_request:
+    # The branches below must be a subset of the branches above

comment_data.body: Now that I think about it this doesn't really make much difference, this is an unnecessary nitpick. Disregard it. PR looks good to go.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,11 @@
 name: "CodeQL"
 
 on:
+  push:
+    branches: [ "master" ]
+  pull_request:
+    # The branches below must be a subset of the branches above

comment_regular_data.body: yeah we get security alerts from it. but I don't know how to check it against a PR (before merging the PR). is there a way?
Just add `pull_request` in the `on` field in file `.github/workflows/codeql.yml`.
codeql job took 11 minutes, that doesn't seem too bad. Any objections to enabling it for PRs? Looks like it is smart enough to only warning about new warnings, not existing ones.

No objections. I personally never found the warnings that useful which is why we never enabled it per PR IIRC. You could shave off a minute or two by caching the deps. Slapping on a `- uses: ./.github/actions/cache` before the make step should be enough.

labels.description: automation for build, test, and release
